Then one day a young man named Johnny discovered two important facts that would change the island forever -- the toe-sap was actually quite delicious and each tribe member produced a different flavor. Johnny was hailed as a hero and soon toe-sap became the island's number one export.

Tribe members spent long days gathering toe-sap, however it soon became apparent that the tribal leaders could influence the toe-sap market, making some varieties more valuable.

As members of the tribe, players take turns collecting varieties of toe-sap. They can also offer cows to the tiny sea-going Cownivores in order to collect toe-sap more quickly. At the end of the game, the players influence the tribal leaders using shells and their remaining cows to dictate the price of each variety of toe-sap.

29109.description:
Dust is a strategy board game of conquest and control. Seize power sources and capitals, develop your infrastructure, and build and wield vast, high-tech armies in your bid for global domination.

Players will probably recognize the map as that of Earth, but what they will not see are any borders or nations. In the world of Dust, the unending war and the new technologies have altered the political face of Earth beyond all recognition.

At the beginning of each turn, players select a card from their hand. This card represents their strategy for the coming turn and to a large extent dictates the actions a player can take.

During their production phase, players spend production points to buy additional factories and units. Each individual unit type has its own unique statistics and effects, so players have to carefully consider the composition of their armies.

In combat, players alternate rolling dice and destroying units until one side has been eliminated (either due to casualties or retreats) or a cease-fire is declared.

At the end of each game round, players score victory points for power sources, capitals, and majorities they control. The player who controls the most land areas earns bonus victory points, as does the player who controls the most sea areas and the player who controls the most production centers. The first player to amass a set number of victory points while also controlling a capital is the winner.

Only once a player has amassed at least half the victory points required to win can he or she attack an enemy capital. Once the war has been so escalated, however, then all players are free to attack capitals.

Dust English Rules Premium Version http://www.fantasyflightgames.com/ffg_content/Dust/Dust_Rule...
Dust English Rules Epic Version http://www.fantasyflightgames.com/ffg_content/Dust/Dust_Rule...
Backstage http://www.kaleidosgames.com
29109.name: Dust

29110.name: Poldi's Fussball Spiel
29110.description: A soccer game that uses dice to move the ball up and down the field as well as to determine whether a goal is scored.

29111.name: Nya Företagspelet Kapital
29111.description: In this game, players try to make as much money as possible by buying and selling stock. The companies you can buy stock in are actual Swedish companies. Things get shaken up by Unforeseen Event-cards, as well as taxation and meddling from the minister of economics and the minister of budgets. Another unusual feature is that you can take a loan, that last for 15 real-world minutes.

29112.name: Pökaspelet med Ronny & Ragge
29112.description: In this game, the player take on the roles as "raggare" (Swedish fans of beautiful women and American 50's youth culture) and try to get their chosen "pök" (chick) to the gravel pit to do burnout in their "fårrd" (Ford). To do this, they have to collect essential raggar-paraphernalia like sideburns and Brylcreem, all the while avoiding the police cruiser and the slow moving Volvo. The game is based on Byhåla, a popular Swedish TV-show from the early '90s.

29113.name: Sport Dice: Golf
29113.description:
Simple dice game simulating a hole of golf.
A player first rolls the green die to try to get on the green (2 out of 6 chances). Once on the green the player rolls the white die until he sinks the ball (2 in 6 chance).
On the first roll of the green die only, the player has a 1 in 6 chance of hitting a hole in one.

The game comes with a sand timer, which is not used for the main game as described above - players just try to roll certain outcomes on the die as many times as they can in a fixed time.

Other games in this series - Tennis, Soccer and Cricket

29114.name: Sport Dice: Tennis
29114.description:
Simple dice game simulating a tennis match.
The serving player uses the white die and the receiving player uses the green die. Players take turns rolling their die until a point is scored either way.

Two kinds of matches can be played: either play for the best of six games, or each player tries to score as many points as possible in a fixed time (using the timer).

Other games in this series - Golf, Soccer and Cricket

29115.name: Sport Dice: Soccer
29115.description:
Simple dice game simulating a soccer match.
Two dice, a timer, counters, score pad and a pencil are provided.
Other games in this series - Golf, Tennis and Cricket

29116.name: Sport Dice: Cricket
29116.description:
Simple dice game simulating a cricket match.
The game comes with two dice, a sand timer, counters, a pencil and a score pad.
Other games in the series: Golf, Tennis and Soccer

29117.name: Sherpa
29117.description:
Since Edmund Hillary and Tenzing Norgay first climbed Mount Everest in 1953, many mountaineers have attempted to repeat their exploit, but with great difficulty.

In this game, YOU are responsible for a team of mountaineers whose objective is to reach the summit of Everest. You will establish one of the supply camps essential to your climbs. You will manage and move human and material resources while facing many dangers in the mountain.

Beware, a strange creature wanders in these sacred regions. The yeti is no longer a legend...

Embark on this great adventure where the courage of your team-mates will make all the difference.

On your mark, get set, ...go!

29118.description:
FROM White Wolf's website:

The Empire Could Be Yours!

In a vast, fantastic world known as Creation, a dynastic empire called the Realm stood for hundreds of years, presided over by the powerful and cunning Scarlet Empress. She reigned with an absolute hand until the day she mysteriously disappeared, leaving a legacy of ruin. Before long, suitors to the throne dared make their bid for power. You are one of the contenders for the Scarlet Throne, a Dragon-Blooded who has amassed the vast armies, fortunes and magic necessary to seize your destiny. You seek to claim dominions and raise war manses, building power until you have the lore and strength to claim the Imperial Manse for your own.

Exalted: War for the Throne is a strategy board game for two to five players set in the world of Exalted®. Players amass legions, coin and essence, and bring all of their allies, will and luck to bear to claim the seat of power and become the new emperor of the Realm.

This game includes:

• A fold-out board with a map of the Blessed Isle, the battleground for the throne

• 5 different aspects from which to choose, all with their own playing pieces and unique powers

• 50 Events Cards and 25 Charm Cards with which to attack, deceive and stymie opponents

• All the dice you need to play

ISBN: 978-1-58846-542-9
29118.name: Exalted: War for the Throne

boardgamefamily.7757: From RPG books to board games

29119.name: Party Pooper
29119.description:
Party Pooper is the spontaneous party game that will have players pointing in all directions to discover who’s the party pooper and who’s the party animal.

One player rolls the die, which tells if they will be selecting a "party pooper" (person least likely to) or "party animal" (person most likely to). They then read a card containing one of the 432 hypothetical scenarios (such as "a friend suspects her husband of cheating on her and wants you to follow him and take pictures"). Each other player then decides whom they think the reader will choose as most/least likely to do such a thing. The reader says "1-2-3-Choose" and everyone points their finger at someone (you can choose yourself, if you wish). If you choose the person the reader chose, you get a chip. The reader gets a chip for each player who chooses the person they picked. After everyone has been the reader 2 or 3 times (depending on the number of players), the game is over and whoever has the most chips wins.

29120.name: Later Mater!
29120.description:
A game similar in play to Perfection, but with a 3D Cars theme.

From the back of the box: "Race to put Mater back together. But don't just 'tool around.' -- You have to be fast to beat the clock. Because when his parts fly, it's time to say goodbye. Later Mater!"

29121.name: The Junk Yard Game
29121.description:
In "The Junk Yard", players (solo or with a partner or even in teams) attempt to knock down targets with a steel ball, propelled by flippers. Rubber bands provide the tension for the flippers and drop targets (tin cans, boots, etc).
It is a simple dexterity game, but can provide many hours of fun. The "Keep Out" targets cause you to lose the ball, and the targets have various point amounts, with the center 500 targets being easy to drain down the middle.

Players/Teams can compete to get the highest score.

29122.description:
"It's Grandma Edna's birthday and she longs for her favorite, apple pie. The family gets up early in order to gather all the ingredients from around the farm; apples have to be picked, the grain ground and the cow milked. Everybody is in a hurry as they all want to be the first to surprise Grandma Edna with their apple pie.

Who will, with a bit of luck and a good overview, be the quickest to collect all the ingredients?"

This game may be played cooperatively or competitively. Players choose a final food (pie, sandwich, etc) and must assemble the ingredients from around the farm. Some items are one step, such as gathering apples, some are multi-step such as feeding hay to the cow to obtain milk which is then processed into cheese.

Bonus advanced instructions for including cow patties into the equation, possibly a gaming first!
29122.name: Auf Dem Lande

29123.name: The Rottnest Island Game
29123.description:
This is an educational game, endorsed by the Rottnest Island Authority and (heavily) sponsored by Agfa Film. It's a standard Roll and Move game with a single path and a start and end. The first half of the path is by boat from the mainland to the island, the second half is by bike on the island itself. The main theme, not surprising given the sponsorship, is photographing wildlife.

As usual with these sorts of games, various points along the path cause things to happen, mostly drawing a card of some sort. You win by getting a photograph of a quokka and getting to the end of the path. There are a group of six quokka photo squares, such that you can't possibly miss it on the way through.

The main educational content of the game is a small brochure with (tourist) information about the island.

29124.name: Eye-Cons
29124.description:
From the bottom of the box:

Don't let your "eyes be conned"!

Match the most "icon" tiles by removing them from the tray in 60 seconds...and win!

Each player takes turns matching the tiles. Set the 60-second timer and GO! Pull exact matching tiles from the specially designed box tray using your "magic" suction wand as fast as you can. But be careful--only exact matches count!

Players count their tiles--the most matches win.

EYE-CONS is also designed for solitaire or team play, and is always great for the whole family.

29125.name: Elections The Race to the White House
29125.description:
The object of the game is to have the most electoral votes. The game ends when the players have won all the states.

Players start with a random home state and four cards, each of which represents a random number of votes. Each player also has two pawns, one starts on the assigned home state; the other on the “Campaign Starts” space on the track. In turn, a player rolls two dice and advances one’s pawn counterclockwise around the track. The space on which a player lands may award the player vote cards, call for a chance card, allow a TV debate (giving a opportunity to steal an opponent's state) or call for an election. When an election is called for, the player moves one’s own pawn to an adjacent state. The players declare how many vote cards each will commit to the election. All the votes are revealed and the player, who committed the most votes without exceeding the state’s limit, as printed on the gameboard, is awarded the state and its electoral votes.

30759.name: HeroCard Orc Wars Ranger Expansion Deck

29126.description:
Deep within the orcish caverns, the drums begin to beat. High in the treetops, the watch sounds the horns of the hunt. The Clans are on the move, the ancient war begins anew. The Elven Champions gather, test their weapons, draw up their resolve.

Under the earth, the Orcish King rails against the Elves, exhorting his troops to blood-frenzy. The Queen of the Elves bids her heroes to her, impresses upon them the nature of their task. Tonight the battle will rage. A thousand Orcs will come to slaughter, and a handful of Elves will return the favor.

HeroCard OrcWars is an asymmetrical fantasy game of fierce combat for two players. OrcWars comes as a two player game with the Paladin and Orc King hero decks. It can be expanded to four players with additional HeroCard decks and figures.

HeroCard OrcWars is expanded by:


HeroCard Orc Wars Ranger Expansion Deck
HeroCard Orc Wars Sorceress Expansion Deck
29126.name: HeroCard Orc Wars

29127.name: Unauthorized Dr. Who CCG
29127.description:
A fan created free to print CCG based on Dr Who (not related in anyway to the Doctor Who Collectible Card Game published by M.M.G. Ltd.)

From the website:
In the spirit of Who, the villains (Enemies) attempt to reach Goals played on Spacetime cards to score points. Meanwhile, the Doctor and his Allies try to stop them and score those points first. Each player plays both his own TARDIS crew and the Enemies their opponent’s TARDIS will face. First player to 10 points (and Reaching and Opposing at least one Goal) wins.

29128.name: 100 Years War
29128.description:
A public domain adaptation of Havoc: The Hundred Years War using a regular deck of cards.

Aside from differences in number (players are dealt 5 cards, only 2 cards are placed as "recruits", etc.) and cosmetic differences (2s are used in place of "Dogs", Jokers as pairs of Dogs, etc.) the significant differences is the use of the face up recruit cards and a randomly drawn card to determine the point value of each battle at the moment it is called. This changes the game considerably as it eliminates the role of strategy about future battles, which is an important element of Havoc.

29129.name: Canal Boat Race
29129.description:
This is a simple roll and move style game based on the British waterways of the 19th Century.

Players must negotiate a series of canals to get to the wharf, collect coal and return to the Paper mill.

Players take it in turn to take cards from a pile and move the number of spaces shown on the card. Some cards give specific bonuses like extra movement.

Also included are the rules for a more complex version of the game called Boatman's Bluff. This uses the same components but adds a bit more strategy to the game.

It was published in association with the British Waterways Board

29130.name: Zero Zero
29130.description: In this game, you begin in the middle of the ocean and navigate shark-infested waters! You become an explorer and a pirate as you overcome formidable adversaries in your quest to reach the awe-inspiring volcano, the cozy igloo in the far North, the idyllic tropical beach and the thrilling amusement park. The hero of this great adventure is the first player to land a game piece on each of the four dream destinations in cold, mild, and hot climates utilizing dice rolls combining plus [warm] and minus [cool] symbols as well as number rolls.

29132.name: Monopoly: Turkish or Istanbul
29132.description: This is simply the Turkish version of Monopoly. It is essentially the same as the standard Monopoly game and other variations, but in Turkish with the properties all being places in Istanbul. In the current version, two of the railroads are replaced with ferry terminals. The chance and community chest cards are apparently based on the British version and thus lack pictures aside from an arrow for advancing to Go and bars for going to jail. They also differ slightly from the modern American cards and are closer to the older American version.

29133.name: Jackson's Foot Cavalry
29133.description:
Jackson's Foot Cavalry

The game will a block game with point to point movement covering Stonewall Jackson's classic 1862 Valley Campaign. The game system will be using our Forged in Fire rules with adjustments for the situation facing both Union and Confederate commanders in the Shenandoah Valley. Supply and surprise will be critical as Jackson races up and down the Valley fighting one Union force after another as the Union try to trap the Confederates. The game will include a main campaign as well as several shorter scenarios. Playable in 3-4 hours for the full campaign with 1-2 hours for scenarios. Victory is determined by how many Union troops the Confederate player can force the Union player to keep in the Valley. The Union player will try to keep the bare minimum of troops in the Valley to prevent the Confederate player from obtaining certain objectives.

According to Worthington's June 1, 2011 update this game will be the first in a series including games on the Vicksburg, Gettysburg, Overland, and Atlanta campaigns as well as an update of Forged in Fire: The 1862 Peninsula Campaign.

29134.description: An expansion for Hold the Line. Scenarios will be playable in 30-90 minutes. The game will cover the battles of the Mexican-American war that developed so many of the great (and some not so) commanders of the American Civil War. More information will be forthcoming as it develops on this title.
29134.name: Hold The Line: The Mexican-American War Expansion Set

29135.name: A.K.A.
29135.description:
The game plays similarly to games like Balderdash in which players make up a meaning to a phrase and everybody votes on which they think is the real phrase. In this game, however, players are trying to guess the correct description to the scientific name of a plant or animal.

The game contains 968 plants & animals on 242 cards.

29136.name: Djungle
29136.description:
The Djungle deck has 11 cards with funny animals on them in 4 different colours, giving a total of 44 cards.

The players collect points during 4 rounds, but each round uses different rules:

- 1st round: after a card is drawn, a player must try to imitate that animal's voice to collect points
- 2nd round: the rules are adapted from "Pit", but played with this deck of cards
- 3rd round: the rules are taken from "Hearts"
- 4th round: the rules are taken from "Uno"

The player with the most points after 4 rounds is the winner.

29137.name: Maya & Miguel Piñata Party Card Game
29137.description:
It's Piñata Party time!

Join Maya & Miguel for this fast-paced card game. Uno, dos, tres! play your cards quickly and in sequence until all of them are used, or until someone shouts, "La Piñata!" Ages 6 and up

Skills: Reading Required

29138.name: Katamino Duo
29138.description:
Katamino Duo – a.k.a., Katamini – is a junior version of Katamino, with two players competing on separate game boards (or possibly one game board divided into smaller spaces) to fill all of the empty spaces first. The game is played over a number of rounds, with each round becoming progressively harder.

Katamino Duo also works as a solitaire puzzle, with the solver trying to fit the pieces onto the playing area in different ways.

29139.name: Lingo
29139.description:
Lingo is a 5 or 6 letter word guess game. The first letter is given. A little like Mastermind, after a word is given, the correct letters are marked. A different mark is given for letters on the correct position.

Each correct word will given you numbers, which you can then remove from you bingo-card. The first to have a line with 5 crosses on its bingo-card wins the game.

Note: This game is based on a Dutch TV-show.

29140.description:
A Jr. version of Tumblin-Dice. This game uses 2 sets dice instead of 4. The board is smaller and has only two 4X areas instead of three.

A dexterity dice game consisting of two sets of colored dice one either slides, rolls, or flicks down a stepped surface. Usually one slides the die for better accuracy. After each person has slid their 4 dice, points are scored. You score the die roll times either 1X, 2X, 3X, or 4X depending on which area of the board the die is on. (Dice which land in the 0X region are immediately removed from play.) High scoring rolls are targets for opponents. Four rounds are played and the player with the most points win.
29140.name: Tumblin-Dice Jr.

29141.name: Tip
29141.description:
Tip simulates the well known Soccer-Toto sweepstakes. Instead of 12 real soccer games, 12 rounds of Tip card game are played.

There are 96 cards in total:
- 28 x "1" (7 cards in red, yellow, blue and green)
- 28 x "X" (7 cards in red, yellow, blue and green)
- 28 x "2" (7 cards in red, yellow, blue and green)
- 7 x "V", black/dark yellow coloured
- 4 x "Combi", each with 3 of the 4 colours above
- 1 x "Trick" with all 4 colors

Each player plays is dealt 10 cards and then secretly writes down his tip (1, x or 2). During play, each player tries to collect a winning hand, which consists of 1 set of 4 and 2 sets of 3 cards.

Points can be won for having the winning hand as well as for having marked the correct tip.

At the end of the 12 rounds, the total number of correct tips are summarized and a last payout of points takes place.
The player with the most points is the winner of the game.

29142.name: I Spy Eagle Eye
29142.description: This matching game is based on the popular I Spy series of books. The game includes four boards filled with pictures of various objects. A deck of thirty cards includes one matching card for each of those objects. Each turn, a card is turned over. The first player to find the matching object on the boards wins that round. The first to get six matching cards wins.

29143.name: Blue Dragon RPCG
29143.description:
Each year for the past ten years, purple clouds would appear, and bring disasters to people around the world.
When their village is attacked again Shu, Kluke, and Jiro fight back against the fin that appears to kill the people. However, they discover it is a strange machine. But even after damaging it, it goes back to the flagship, with the three still on it.
There, they encounter constant attacks from metal soldiers until they discover three orbs of light. After hearing a voice tell them to swallow the orbs, they do and discover their shadows grow into monsters; Kluke's becomes a blue phoenix, Jiro's a blue minotaur, and Shu's a blue dragon. They then fight the ship's captain, Nene, and discover that Nene is behind the yearly attacks on their town. He easily defeats them, and they can barely make it to an escape capsule. They then land far from home and must then journey to find a way to save their land.
Following their escape from Nene's air fortress, they encounter more people from towns that have also fallen victim to the purple clouds, and decide that they must try to stop Nene from continuing to bring ruin on their world.

This is a CCG currently with 2 volumes (sets) that plays out in this world...

29144.description:
City Game, is a game similar to Trivial Pursuit where players must to choose the correct answer among three in the race to conquer the cities of the world that celebrated the Olympic Games in the past, the fist is Athens in 1896 the last is Atlanta in 1996

The questions are based in typical things of each city,and players roll a die and move along the world to complete all cities. First player to complete all win the game.

The game is in Spanish and the components are:
- 1 big game board of the world
- 1000 cards question-answers
- 10 counters
- 3 dices, one of numbers and two specials with a letter to correspond a part of an area of the world
- 1 rulebook
29144.name: City Game: El Juego de las 20 Ciudades Olímpicas

29145.name: Quick Checkers
29145.description: Award winning introductory form of checkers with a smaller 6x6 board covered with instructions to help children remember the set-up and legal plays. Included in the packaging is a foldout pictorial list of easy lessons and alternate rules to make the game intriguing and interesting for the growing player. The board is double-sided and has a regular (though still labeled) 8x8 board on the reverse.

29146.description:
Okey is a traditional Turkish game, similar to Rummikub.

Players manage their hand to make runs and sets. The first one to use all his pieces wins the game.

The game needs paying careful attention on the opponent's discarded pieces and plan the new series according to them, as there is only a pair of every piece.
29146.name: Okey

boardgamefamily.24439: Card Games: Draw and Discard Games

29147.name: Brocante
29147.description:
Brocante is a interesting trade game, with a significant bit of luck, but also an important tactical element.

The players earn money while playing the lottery, and by reselling the objects which they accrue. The easy way is in the price of the objects. In each type, there are four prices. Most expensive is to be sold first. The prices are 3500, 2500, 1500 and 1000. Players collect the eight objects in a set, without doubles.

Players try to buy the objects that would complete other players' sets, especially to double the price when selling to the player who needs the object (and reap greater profits).

But, while objects are purchased from most-to-least expensive, they are sold least-to-most expensive.

29148.name: Sherlock Holmes
29148.description: The players move figures representing Holmes and Watson around a board representing London trying to uncover 6 clue cards relating to a specific mystery before their opponents. There are no dice or spinners, just tactical movements based on deduction and skill.

29149.name: Britain's Brainiest
29149.description:
A game based on a TV quiz show that challenges your perceptions of stereotypes !

Over 2,200 questions across 52 categories. Questions & teasers to occupy the most active of minds & challenge the cleverest of clogs. Whether with your family or with friends, play at home & experience the excitement & challenge of the TV show.

Will you be revealed as the Brainiest ?

29150.name: Thrice
29150.description:
The object of the game is to position your own dice in a row next to each other. The dice must be in a straight line, not around a corner. They may be in any numerical order.

A simple dice strategy game for all ages.

29151.name: Treasure Quest
29151.description:
The quest for the "Ultimate Dungeon Crawl" is over.

"Treasure Quest" is here...

An adaption of WOTC's D20 D&D system, D&D Mini's game and inspired by adventure board and video games, past and present, Treasure Quest takes player-heroes into the depths of treasure-rich and monster-ridden dungeons. The goal is to get in, get the treasure, and get out.
Alive.

Using your own grid/hex based maps/ boards, D&D miniatures and scenary, Treasure Quest is a streamlined set of rules for adventuring, combat, dungeon exploration, and treasure/experience collection with or without a DM.

Version 5.0 featuring new streamlined mechanics, solo play options and a more comprehensive rules guide is now available as a free download.

29152.name: Yggdrasil
29152.description: Taken from the ASG description: Yggdrasil is an abstract strategy game that takes 2-4 players to the world of Scandinavian mythology and its many capricious gods. Thor, Odin, Frigg and Loki are reborn to impose their will within the nine worlds. Yggdrasil, the tree of Odin, is the force that keeps this fragile system functioning. The players must manipulate the runic stones in order to gain the most points and thus win the game.

29153.name: We Dunit, New Black History
29153.description:
Listen in American Games #4157. 1965, Ethnic, Card Game.

Submit a better description and contact Admin Skelebone for a GeekGold reward.

We Dunit is a game played somewhat like Charades.

29154.name: All American Handicap
29154.description:
Listed in American Games #4157a. Circa 1950s, Sports, Horse Racing, Record Game.

Submit a better description and contact Admin Skelebone for a GeekGold reward.

29155.name: WABC-TV's Media Careers
29155.description:
Listed in American Games #4162. 1977, Advertising, Comics, Board Game.

The object of the game is to win by becoming Senior VP Media first. Career points are acquired to reach the goal. Each of the number of job levels has 6 points. The job levels are Rookie Buyer, Assistant Buyer, Buyer, Buyer Supervisor, Assoc Media Director, V.P. Media director and lastly the goal Senior VP Media.

The equipemnt is a board with 4 pawns for the players, 10 decks of cards, 2 dice, a "The Boss" sign, and four black pegs with a horseshoe shaped scoring track in the box bottom. Nine of the decks of cards are for the demographics categories, the tenth is for the "Challenge the Boss" deck. You can only challenge the boss when on a buy square. The board has an outside track for player movement.

Players get 2 experience points for passing "Start." They can gain or lose experince points when they "buy" demographic results on the board's nine different demographic categories based on age and sex. You can get "fired" and sent to the "Unemployemnt Office" sqaure on the board. You remain there until you get rehired by roll of 9 to 12 on the dice. You can become the boss by getting promoted. There are sqaures with special instructions for "Take a long lunch", "Leave briefcase in cab", and "Work Overtime."

29156.name: Music #1
29156.description:
Listed in American Games #4163. 1984, Music, Board Game.

A roll-and-move game in which players try to complete an 8-bar staff and song title by collecting notes and words. While there is education value in teaching recognition of music notation and theory, the game's mechanics have little to do with music.

From the Manufacturer's instructions:
"No musical knowledge required. Just read, count, and roll dice."

"A game of chance by rolling the dice. Each player will encircle board several times in one game. Player keeps moving his token around the board the number of spaces indicated by the total sum of the two dice. Each space landed upon and each card drawn directs the movements of teh player. No one is safe even in his own play area. He must follow directions of space landings. There is no blocking, no bumping players off spaces and no back obligations. First player to fill his staff with notes and complete a song title is the winner. It can be very frustrating at times with continual gains and losses; such as real composers go through as they create a song. A player who has the least notes or words during the game can be the winner at the last minute though it appears he is losing."

"Object of Game: A player must fill his 8 BAR STAFF with 4 beats to each measure containing the right amount of notes and complete a SONG TITLE of four words or more which say something."

"EQUIPMENT: Board with indicated play spaces, four 8 bar staffs, four tokens to represent each composer, two dice, 500 words, 50 whole notes (clear discs) 50 half notes (white discs) 75 quarter notes (black discs) and 75 Directional cards."

29157.name: Pennant Drive
29157.description:
Listed in American Games #4165. 1980, Sports, Baseball, Board Game.

Submit a better description and contact Admin Skelebone for a GeekGold reward.

29158.name: 3 Point Landing
29158.description:
Listed in American Games, #4172. 1940s, Travel, Air, Board game.

Three Point Landing -- Race your planes through all their destinations -- Here’s a thrilling game Full of sensations

Three Point Landing consists of a play board illustrated with a map of the United States and part of Canada, 24 destination cards, a spinner and wooden figures representing airplanes, (in the deluxe edition the map on the play board also includes Central and South America, and 36 instead of 24 destination cards.

Advance Games Corp, N.Y.C.
No.242 1942 Made in USA

Directions for Playing
Distribute the destination cards equally among all the players. Each player is also given a figure which represents his aeroplane. The object of “THREE POINT LANDING” is to cover all cities listed on your destination cards and then return to the starting place, namely “LaGuardia Field” New York City, before your opponents. Whoever returns first is the winner, before beginning study your route cards, and the map to determine the shortest round trip route, and arrange your cards accordingly. The players spin the dial in turn, and moves along the desired route, advancing the same amount of spaces as the spin. He must land on every city listed on the cards even though he spins a greater number. (Example: if he is three spaces from one of his cities and spins a six he still only advances three spaces to the city and then waits his next turn.) If a stop is made at a space with a “FORCED LANDING” or a “MOTOR REPAIRING” picture - ---in red clolor---the player must return to the last numbered town, it is necessary to spin the exact number of spaces to LaGuardia Field, New York City in order to land there at the finish. (Example: if there are three spaces left to the field, a three must be spun in order to land there.) The cities on the map have numbers that correspond to the numbers on the destination cards, so that small children will have no difficulty in identifying the position of the cities on the map.

29159.name: Bengalee: The Game of the East
29159.description:
Listed in American Games #4172a. Circa 1940s, Adventure, Board Game.

Submit a better description and contact Admin Skelebone for a GeekGold reward.

29160.name: Happy Horse
29160.description:
Listed in American Games #4172b. Circa 1940s, Animal, Board Game.

Simple game with extremely bright and colorful box. The game consists of spinning a top and the top then goes into different areas of the game board and points are awarded depending on it's final resting place.

29161.name: Airderby
29161.description:
Listed in American Games, #4174. 1950, Travel, Air, Board game.

Submit a better description and contact Admin Skelebone for a GeekGold reward.

29162.name: Siege
29162.description:
Listed in American Games, #4175. 1976, Military, Board Game.

A typical move-and-capture game, such as Draugths or Checkers. The board represents a castle and a perimeter. Players move along paths that connect spaces together. Capture is by jumping over an adjacent piece to any vacant space beyond and is mandatory. Both players have the same pieces - one King, four Knights and eight pawns. The pieces have a hierarchy where a piece may not capture a more important piece.

One player is the Defender and the other the Attacker. The Defender starts his pieces from the middle of the board whilst the attacker starts on the perimeter. The object is to make the other player resign by eliminating enough pieces that there is no point in continuing.

The rules are extensive with many elaborations, hints and examples of play.

29163.name: Mighty Mouse Spin Targets Game
29163.description:
Listed in American Games, #4176. 1958, Cartoon, Action Game.

Submit a better description and contact Admin Skelebone for a GeekGold reward.

29164.name: Political Influence, An American Tradition
29164.description:
Listed in American Games, #4177. 1994, Political, Board Game.

Submit a better description and contact Admin Skelebone for a GeekGold reward.

29165.name: Questionable Integrity
29165.description:
Listed in American Games, #4178. 1992, Q&A, Board Game.

Submit a better description and contact Admin Skelebone for a GeekGold reward.

29166.name: All About Cumberland, Maryland
29166.description:
Listed in American Games #4180. 1981, Cities & Town, Board Game.

Presumably, like the other All about... games, an -opoly clone with information centered on Cumberland, Maryland.

29167.name: All About Minneapolis
29167.description:
Listed in American Games #4181. 1981, Cities & Town, Board Game.

Presumably, like the other All about... games, an -opoly clone with information centered on Minneapolis.

29168.name: Baseball
29168.description:
An early card driven pitch-by-pitch baseball simulation designed for two players.

Game Contents: Playing Board, Deck of 36 Baseball Cards, 4 Wooden Markers for Batter and Base Runners, 2 Wooden Markers for Strikes and Balls, 1 Wooden Marker for Outs, 1 Wooden Marker for Runs Scored in an Inning, Score Sheet, Instructions.

To play, the cards are shuffled and held in the hand of the player at bat. The player in the field calls a pitch (fastball, curve, slow ball, drop, or knuckle ball). The result of the pitch is read from the top card. Pitch results include strike, ball, foul ball, hit batsman, wild pitch, balk or "field play."

When "field play" is the result of the pitch, the card is turned over to the Field Play side to determine the play outcome. Different play outcomes are included on each card, and the specific outcome used is based upon the number of outs and the number and location of baserunners.

After the result for a particular pitch has been determined, that card is discarded and play continues with the next card in the deck.

Although the game concept is simple, it works quite well, and play can be very competitive. However, the strategic aspects of baseball are ignored. There is no bunting, hit and run, positioning of the defense, etc.

This game has one notable oddity. The game board is a depiction of a baseball field with defenders drawn at the normal defensive positions. The defenders are numbered based upon standard baseball scoring conventions, except that the corner outfielders are reversed--that is, the rightfielder is shown as "7" and the leftfielder as "9."

This game was produced and marketed for at least 10 years under a variety of names: "Baseball", "Baseball Game for Young America", and "Little League Baseball".

29169.name: Big Chief
29169.description: Listed in American Games, #4183. Circa 1950s, Western, Board Game. Object of game: the object of the game is to move along the game board. In some cases this requires doing it 2 or three times while trying to acquire 5 feather cards. At the beginning of the game the first 8 spaces have actual Indian sign languages and you have to learn those signs to proceed along with the game. Whoever takes 5 large feather cards wins by becoming BIG CHIEF. This game looks as if it was re-done with somewhat similar if not easier rules in the mid 1960's under the name Little Chief

29170.name: Emmett Kelly's Circus Game
29170.description:
From the Box:

"It's fun to see the Circus. It's more fun to be a part of the Circus. This game of mine takes you into circus life. You can follow the track around the 3 rungs with the Clowns and the Ringmaster. You can build the various circus acts - the animal acts, the trapeze acts, the tumblers, the jugglers and others. There's a prize for each act you complete and whoever gets the most prizes, wins. Let's play!"

This game uses a simplistic card drawing and set collection method to move players around the board. Movement around the board seems to serve no purpose other than to kill time, as all the game mechanic is from drawing cards and placing cards on the game board to make sets. Points are accumulated when sets are completed, or when indicated by the type of card drawn at the beginning of the player's turn.

OBJECT
The object of the game is to win the most Emmett Kelly Prize Disks. A Prize is won when a player

Plays a Circus Act Card that completes and Act.
Draws an Emmett Kelly Prize Card
Stops on an Emmett Kelly space in the game board track.





SETUP
Place the Emmett Kelly Prize Disks in a pile to one side.

Mix up the action cards and place them face down in a pile near the game board

All players select a colored Playing Piece and place it on the matching Ringmaster space on the board. the player that chose Green goes first and then play proceeds to the left

Each turn starts by drawing an Action Card from the face down pile.

ACTION CARDS - WHAT THEY MEAN
Circus Act Cards. Each Circus Act card has a picture matching a part of an Act in the Circus, menagerie or Side Show. When Drawn, the player looks on the board for part of an Act it matches and places the card on it. The player also moves the playing piece the number of spaces shown on the card. moves are always in a clockwise direction.
Whenever a player draws and plays an Act Card that completes an Act, he takes one Emmett Kelly Prize Disk.

Emmett Kelly Cards. When drawn, the player moves ahead to the next Emmett Kelly space on the game board track and takes one Emmett Kelly Prize Disk.

Blue Clown Cards. When drawn, the player moves his playing piece the number of spaces shown on the card.

Red Clown Cards. When drawn, the player moves his playing piece the number of spaces shown in the card. Also if any player (whether the one drawing the Red Clown Card or not) has more Prizes than the others, that player returns one Prize to the Prize pile. If two or more players are tied for most Prizes, none is given up.

Ringmaster Cards. When drawn, the player moves to the next Ringmaster space and takes another turn.

Clown Dog Card. When drawn, the player moves to the next Clown Dog space and loses his next turn.

The Circus Act Cards are played on the board. All the other Action Cards are piled face up to one side after they are drawn and used.

WINNING
When all the Acts on the game board have been completed, by covering them with matching cards, the player with the most Emmett Kelly Prizes is the winner.

29171.name: Football
29171.description:
Listed in American Games, #4186. 1946, Sports, Football, Board game.

This two-player football game featured a folding game board (football field), 36 play cards, a metal football, a first down marker, and wooden markers to track the down, quarter, and score.

Play begins with the play cards shuffled and placed face down on the board. The player on offense calls a play from a limited menu (long pass, short pass, end run, line buck, punt, field goal), and the top card is then turned over to determine the result of the play.

There is a good variety of play outcomes, including fumbles, intercepted passes, and penalties. However, the game was designed in an era when single wing formations dominated, passing was relatively rare, and offenses were often "three yards and a cloud of dust." As a result, long advances from scrimmage are rare. The longest possible gain is 41 yards on a long pass.

Defense does not come into play, and the player on defense simply must hope that the player on offense fails to achieve successful play outcomes.

One pass through the card deck constitutes a quarter of football.

This game might have nostalgic value for those who played it as youngsters, but there are far better football games available today.

29172.name: Jace Pearson's Tales of the Texas Rangers
29172.description: Based on "Tales of the Texas Rangers," a western adventure old-time radio drama that aired on the NBC radio network from 1950-1952, starring Joal McCrea and directed by Stacey Keach, Sr. The series was adapted for television and aired in the late 1950's, starring Willard Parker.

29173.description:
Made by E.E. Fairchild Corp., this is exactly what the name implys, A children's Rummy card game
with art based off of Peter Rabbit.
29173.name: Peter Rabbit Rummy

29174.name: The Game of Pirate Gold
29174.description:
Listed in American Games, 4190. 1946, Adventure, Board game.

Submit a better description and contact Admin Skelebone for a GeekGold reward.

29175.name: Pot O'Gold
29175.description:
As per the box lid, Pot O'Gold is the "Fortune Telling Game for 2-4 players, young or old".

This is a spin-and-move game similar to The Game of Life. Players spin and move 1 to 6 spaces, following the game track where they will encounter a variety of Lucky and Unlucky events, including finding their "Future Husband or Wife", along the way.

The goal is to reach the Finish Line and "Win A Pile Of Lucky Pieces".

29176.name: Pro Locker Basketball
29176.description:
Listed in American Games, #4192. 1960, Sports, Basketball, Board game.

Submit a better description and contact Admin Skelebone for a GeekGold reward.

29177.name: Round Up
29177.description:
Listed in American Games, #4193. 1946, Western, Board game.

Submit a better description and contact Admin Skelebone for a GeekGold reward.

29178.name: Spaceship
29178.description:
Listed in American Games, #4195. Circa 1940s, Space, Board game.

Submit a better description and contact Admin Skelebone for a GeekGold reward.

29179.name: Space Mouse
29179.description:
Space Mouse was a character on the Woody Woodpecker cartoon television show.

Listed in American Games, #4194. 1964, Space, Animal, Card game.

Submit a better description and contact Admin Skelebone for a GeekGold reward.

29180.name: Spot-A-Plate
29180.description:
Listed in American Games, #4196. Circa 1950s, Miscellaneous, Board game.

This game comes with a playing board consisting of a map of the 48 states, 48 different liscense plates, one from each state, 4 car pieces and a die. Object of the game is to roll the die and try to pick up as many plates as you can. Player who gets the most plates wins the game

29181.name: Sweeps
29181.description:
Listed in American Games.


4197. 1945, Hand with money cover. Sports, Horseracing, Board game



4198. 1945, Man in polka dot suit cover. Sports, Horseracing, Board game



4199. 1945, Three players with money cover. Sports, Horseracing, Board game


Game based on the famous Sweepstakes race run in Ireland. The object of the game is to,of course, win the Sweepstakes Race.

The game comes with 1 die, 4 colored horses with wooden stands, 25 colored markers and 1000 dollars [NOTE: Unknown how many colored cardboard markers and how much money present indicates a complete game. My copy came with a sheet of 27 (9x3) brown markers in addition to 25 already cut-out markers - were 2 sheets of each color provided? Additionally the rules state that each player starts with $1,900 (not $1,000) broken out into 16 $100 bills, 4 $50 bills and 20 $5 bills, meaning there should be at least 64 $100 bills, 16 $50 bills and 80 $5 bills in a complete set, maybe more]. Players move around the board contributing money into the Sweepstakes purse. buying horses, and buying sweepstakes tickets.

If a player lands on a square already owned by another player, the player makes a side bet of 5.00 by paying the fee to the owner of the horse. If that horse eventually wins the owner must pay off the bettor at odds shown below the name and price of his horse.

A player must be on the yellow circuit of the board in order to win. If a roll puts his marker past the "winning post" square on his first time around he must go around the circuit once more. As he hears the 'Winning Post" position a 2nd time he must stop if a roll were to take him past the square and then on another turn re-roll and try again to hit the Winning Post square by exact roll. If he does he takes all the money in the Sweeps Fund, pays off all bets on his horse and then wins the game.

29182.name: Woody Woodpecker
29182.description:
Listed in American Games, #4204. 1968, Cartoon, Card game.

29183.name: Car 54, Where are You?
29183.description:
Listed in American Games, #4206. 1961, TV, Law, Board game.

Submit a better description and contact Admin Skelebone for a GeekGold reward.

29184.name: Highway Traffic Game
29184.description:
Listed in American Games, #4206a. 1957, Travel, Board game.

Submit a better description and contact Admin Skelebone for a GeekGold reward.

29185.name: Ords, The Odyssey in the 21st Century
29185.description:
A space-based game in which players attempt to destroy their enemies' ships and conquer their star systems, thus becoming Emperor of the Galaxy and an ORDS citizen.

Original Game Contents:
1x game board (six different quadrant areas)
1x Wheel of Ords (six sector areas)
3x Dice
6x Moving pieces (tokens)
6x Armadas of ships (ships and fleets)
12x Offensive Weapon Cards
10x Defensive Weapon Cards
6x Star Base Cards
72x Star Cards
14x Transportation Cards
12x In Time of Need Cards
8x Cross the Great Gulf Cards
6x Star Base boards
2x Knowledge Cards
Yeps (paper money)

Listed in American Games, #4208. 1993, Space, Board game.

Submit a better description and contact Admin Skelebone for a GeekGold reward.

29186.name: Chap Acquitted
29186.description:
Listed in American Games, #4210. 1979, Social Concern, Board game.

A 'game' certainly published with a steep agenda. This game references Senator Ted Kennedy's incident in July 1969 where he drove off a bridge on Chappaquiddick Island, into a pond. While Kennedy managed to swim to safety, his passenger, Mary Jo Kopechne drowned. Kennedy left the scene of the accident and was later given a suspended sentence of 2 months in jail.

Senator Kennedy (in reference to this incident) has sometimes been referred to as a 'Chap Acquitted'.

This 'game' appears to challenge the acquittal and cast an unfavorable shadow on Ted Kennedy. The box cover refers to it as a 'Bridge game of sorts' and included a 273 page book entitled - Teddy Bare, the real story of Chappaquiddick.

29187.name: Astro World Game
29187.description:
Listed in American Games, #4213. 1971, Travel, Advertising, Ad game for Airline, Board game.

Submit a better description and contact Admin Skelebone for a GeekGold reward.

29188.name: Popularity Lottery
29188.description:
Listed in American Games, #4217. Circa 1990s, Gambling, Board game.

Submit a better description and contact Admin Skelebone for a GeekGold reward.

29190.name: Maloney's Pub
29190.description:
Collect the most drink chips while traveling through the Pub.

Contents:
• game board
• shamrock cards
• drink chips
• play money
• tokens and die

Listed in American Games, #4219a. 1978, Drinking, Board game.

29191.name: Thrift: A Banking Game
29191.description:
Listed in American Games, #4222. 1963, Economic, Board game, a premium for Lincoln Bank.

Thrift is a quick to learn, exciting game of banking. It is educational and challenging. The game is designed to develop and test basic money handling skills. The object of the game is to be the first player to build a bank account of $2,500.

Equipment:


A playing board, located on box cover
A pack of fortune cards
A supply of paper money
A spinner
A playing piece

29192.name: The Time Machine
29192.description:
Travel through time in the Time Machine exciting Action Game. Move your pawns through four different tracks representing the 18th, 19th, 20th, and 21st centuries. Land on green spaces to collect Time Boost, Achievement, Great Leaders, Invention, Peace, and Science cards while avoid red spaces, which give Disaster, War, and Time Reversal cards. The game utilizes a (30 Day guaranteed) Action Spinner, allowing you to move from 1-5 spaces in each of the different century tracks on the game board. In order to win, you need to be the first player to collect three I.E. Cards from three different decks.

Ages 7 and up

Listed in American Games, #4227a. 1963, Board game.

29193.name: Rocket Patrol Magnet Target Game
29193.description:
Listed in American Games, #4228. Circa 1950s, Space, Action game.

Not so much a board game as a toy. This is no more than magnetic darts.

29194.name: Radaronics
29194.description:
Listed in American Games, #4226. 1946, Military, Board game.

Submit a better description and contact Admin Skelebone for a GeekGold reward.

Military radar game, "Radaronics, The Magic Game With Radar Vision, Featured And Approved By The Quiz Kids, ARC, American Radar Corporation, No. 47, 1946". This games includes inner map insert with spinning mechanism, battery operated light bulb, bottom piece attached to box base with rod for spinner to rotate on, another map insert, 2 dice, plastic markers and 4 hard plastic (bakelite bake lite?) ship boat playing pieces.

29195.name: Treasure Hunt
29195.description:
Listed in American Games, #4201. Circa 1950s, Adventure, Board game.

Submit a better description and contact Admin Skelebone for a GeekGold reward.

29196.name: Bratz Head Gamez
29196.description: It's funky fashion fun as you travel the board, pickin' up cosmetics and accessories to make over your Bratz™ girl! If your Bratz™ is completely made up and you reach the end first, you win!

29197.name: Let My People Go!
29197.description: Passover board game - Journey with the people of Israel as they emerge a free nation from slavery.

29198.description:
From the publisher:

The dice game of champions in the Dungeons & Dragons world.
From the creators of Three-Dragon Ante, the Dungeons & Dragons in-world card game, comes the perfect dice game for D&D players and characters alike. With a roll of the dice, you determine whether to hurl a mug of ale at the warbling bard or smash a chair over the drunken barbarian's back. Treachery and chaos abound, as every game promises a new and hilarious tavern brawling experience. Inside every Inn Fighting box you'll find a rules sheet, a set of 6 special six-sided dice, 1 twenty-sided die, and 52 character cards. Choose a character, trade some dice rolls with your friends, and see who's left standing in the end!
Rob Heinsoo was a Senior Game Designer at Wizards of the Coast, Inc. He co-wrote the Forgotten Realms Campaign Setting, worked on several sets for the Dungeons & Dragons Miniatures Game, and designed the popular Three-Dragon Ante card game.

Release: October 2007

boardgameversion.33957: Wizards of the Coast English edition

29198.name: Inn-Fighting

29199.description:
Victoria Cross II

This is a reprint of Victoria Cross with the battles of Isandlwana, Rorkes Drift, included.

The game that started it all for Worthington Games. Using the Victoria Cross system that was the first game produced by Worthington Games.

Two battles, one great game! The game will include the original Victoria Cross updated with counters, updated rules, and new box. As the British player tries to stem the hordes of Zulu warriors with his trusty Martini-Henry rifle (with a bit of guts behind it!). As the Zulu player can you, through mass and guile, drive the British from your land.

It is up to you to decide!
29199.name: Victoria Cross II

29201.name: Sherlock Holmes:  A Game of Deduction and Suspense
29201.description:
In Sherlock Holmes : A Game of Deduction and Suspense a diamond has been stolen and the detective Sherlock Holmes must discover who has done the crime. There is a single counter representing Sherlock Holmes and the players take turns moving it about the board.

The game is played on the board and with a deck of cards. Each cards has a picture of one of the suspects on it and there are two cards for each suspect. At the start of the game one player shuffles the cards and places one face down in the middle of the board. The remaining cards are then dealt out to the players.

Whenever a player lands on a picture of a suspect they must show any cards of that suspect. If they land on an "investigate" space they can examine a card from another player's hand. And, if they land on the "Scotland Yard" space then all players holding pairs of cards (two cards of the same suspect) must show them. Other spaces have special events on them which cause players to exchange hands and the like.

Play continues until one player thinks they know who the culprit is. They announce their choice and check the card in the middle of the board. If they are correct they are the winner. Otherwise they are out of the game and play continues until someone makes the correct guess.

Sherlock Holmes is a variant of the game Clue . The object is to figure out which card is in the middle of the board. Since there will be two cards for every suspect in the player's hands except for this one the idea is to figure out which card doesn't have a match in another hand.

This game was authorized by the Sir. Arthur Conan Doyle estate.

29202.name: 19th Green
29202.description:
From the box:

"A family golf game that lets you warm up for the Masters"

Up to four players compete in a round of golf using a map of a golf course, a die, and 4 pawns. At each hole, players take turns rolling the die to make their shot. The result of the die roll is checked against provide tables for each of the holes and conditions of play. A table will indicate whether the shot is made and/or the lie of the ball. Each roll of the die is equal to one stroke.

Game contents:
1 golf course map on stiff paper
1 green die
4 generic plastic pawns (red, blue, yellow, green)
3 pages of shot tables on normal paper
5 pages of score sheets on normal paper

Interesting facts:
The "Directions for Play" are printed directly on the outside of the box bottom.

29203.name: Easy Cheesy
29203.description:
Easy Cheesy is a smash & grab to see whose mouse can snatch the most cheese & drop it safely into its own nest ! Watch the mice wobble as they gobble !

Their magnetic mouths are ready to chomp, but their bouncy rubber bodies can send them out of control !

Great fun for the kids !

Contents

1 x Cheeseboard

4 x Rubber mice

4 x Plastic handles

16 x Cheeses

29204.name: The Game of Ocean
29204.description: The Game of OCEAN [Oceanography, Circulation, Ecology, Animals, Navigation]. This interactive question-answer game provides an opportunity for participants to review facts and develop the vocabulary and concepts Science Olympiad participants may encounter in the Oceanography.

29205.name: Meet Me at the Mall
29205.description: Meet Me at the Mall is a mall shopping game in which players rush to purchase items before the mall closes. When the shopping bags are emptied, the player with the largest value of items wins.

29206.name: National Gallery Artist's Card Game
29206.description:
Four card games using the same pack of commemorative cards from the National Gallery. Each card is of very high quality and features one of 52 famous paintings. Two of the games are familiar e.g. snap or memory. Two of the games have been created especially for this pack of cards.

In 'Collector' you are collecting different paintings from different schools in a game akin to Happy Families. In 'Curator' one player acts as a curator for a museum collecting different schools of paintings in exchange for chips (not provided)

29207.description:
From the publisher's website:

The house doesn’t look like it’s going to be standing much longer and the only place you haven’t explored is...
The basement! Not that you haven’t tried. You just haven’t found the key. It has to be in the house somewhere, doesn’t it?
You and your hoodlum friends have decided to hit the Breitenstein house one last time. This time around the goal is the same...Well, there might be one slight difference... Unlocking the basement seems to have set something free...something evil!!!
The Haunting House 4 adds new strategic elements, Hidden bonuses and Automatically collapsing halls

Expands

The Haunting House
29207.name: The Haunting House 4: They Don't Build 'Em Like They Used To

29209.name: Zombie Chow-Down
29209.description: Zombie Chow-Down is a game by Aaron Williams (of Nodwick fame), where players try to be the first to eat two whole human beings. It's a simple dice-rolling game, with the standard sense of humor one would expect from the author. A set of dice are required to play the game; standard dice will work, but the author recommends using body-part dice.

29210.description:
"Catch a wave in Cowabunga!, the brand-new card game of Surfin' Steer and ups and downs! Ride high on the wave, dodging obstacles as you play number cards to raise or lower the water level. If you can finish the game with the least amount of wipeouts, you'll be the big Cow-huna!"

Re-implements:

Fettnapf... in Sicht
29210.name: Cowabunga

29211.description:
From Bent Castle Workshop webpage:

"A new breed of villainy descends on Infinity city. To defeat it you will need more skill than ever before. Armed with division and decimals see if you are up to the challenge. The 60 card expansion deck includes Rules, 24 new villains (12 cards), 11 new superheroes (33 cards), and 15 new weapons."

Expansion for Numbers League.
29211.name: Numbers League: Infinity Level Expansion Deck

29212.name: Screw the I.R.S.
29212.description:
From the box: "A fast moving, exciting game for 2 to 6 people collecting deductions to equal salary and pay no tax! This game was designed for fun! The makers of this game do not advocate cheating on taxes or paying less than anyones share."

Game is played over several rounds and the winner is the player that hits a target point limit. You play a salary card and on subsequent rounds, play deduction cards to equal your salary (leaving you with $0 to pay the IRS).

29213.description:
This boardgame has all the familiar aspects of rugby including rules, terminology, tactics, and of course, excitement.

Players play their games against the board. A single game is played by traveling from the kick-off square to the final whistle square. Tries/conversions are scored during each game.

Essentially, the board creates realistic results that players record on a league table. Each player has their own league table for recording results. When each players league table has been completed, the player with the most league points wins the game.
29213.name: League Leader Rugby

29214.name: League Leader Soccer
29214.description:
This boardgame has all the familiar aspects of soccer including rules, terminology, tactics, and of course, excitement.

Players play their games against the board.
A single game is played by traveling from the kick-off square to the final whistle square.
Goals are scored during each game.

Essentially, the board creates realistic results that players record on a league table.
Each player has their own league table for recording results.
When each players league table has been completed, the player with the most league points wins the game.

29215.description:
From the publisher:

HOT STOVE PACK 2 follows in the footsteps of its predecessor based on popular demand and we think this new batch of scenarios will get your dice rolling, and how!

In addition to a brand new map you receive FOUR scenarios to use on it. The terrain features HILLTOP ACTION and multiple heights will be contested like never before. The versatile new map included with HOT STOVE PACK 2 is not only perfect to depict HILL 75.9 (aka “Devil’s Hill”), Nijmegen, but serves just as well as the setting for the classic struggle at HILL 253.5, PONYRI.

Another hilltop, just outside of ROMNY, RUSSIA is the setting of a new scenario utilizing the AFV Card provided for the Pz Sf IVa tank-destroyer, aka ‘Dickermax”. The fighting at MALTOT is also recreated with Tigers aplenty.

This wouldn’t be a HOT STOVE PACK if there wasn’t a special bonus included and this time around ATSers have the opportunity to MAX OUT their purchases of NIKITOVKA and TOKTONG PASS with two new scenarios, one pitting Italian APLINI against elite French S.E.S. troops in the French Alps. The other brings a swarm of N.K.P.A. troops against US Marines, Pershings and recoilless rifles at OBONG-NI RIDGE 1950.

HOT STOVE PACK 2 consists of FOUR new World War II scenarios PLUS TWO BONUS SCENARIOS for a total of SIX, printed on cardstock. Each scenario is playable on the new HOT STOVE PACK 2 map, with one bonus scenario requiring the use of HOT STOVE MAP 1. This series is meant for the serious ATS player and should not be missed!

Expands

Advanced Tobruk
Scottish Corridor: Lion Rampant
29215.name: Hot Stove Pack 2

29216.name: League Leader Gaelic Football
29216.description:
This boardgame has all the familiar aspects of Gaelic football including rules, terminology, tactics, and of course, excitement.

Players play their games against the board.
A single game is played by traveling from the throw in square to the final whistle square. Goals/points are scored during each game.

Essentially, the board creates realistic results that players record on a league table.
Each player has their own league table for recording results.
When each players league table has been completed, the player with the most league points wins the game.

29217.name: CAGE's Open Invitation Golf Classic
29217.description:
Open Invitation Golf Classic is a golf game which uses a unique card drawing system for moving. Each card contains for lines of variable length that each cross to edges of the card. These are used to determine where the ball is thrown. Each line represents a different stroke: the drive, the chip, the sandtrap, and the putt.

The board has 9 holes but is intended to be played as a 9 or 18 hole course.

29218.name: Princeps Machiavelli
29218.description:
From the publisher's website...

Princeps Machiavelli is a new concept of strategy cards game. It’s a wargame inspired by The Prince of Niccolò Machiavelli. This game shows accurately Machiavelli's thoughts about War and Politic in the Renaissance World.

Live the fights between noble families and use diplomatic weapons to lead your Principality to glory!

29219.name: The Ultimate Football Quiz Kit
29219.description:
Part of the Ultimate Quiz Kits series.
The ultimate football quiz – over 2,000 questions for every level, from beginner to buff.

Contains everything required for a fun quiz at home, at work or in the pub.

The CD-ROM allows you to print off questions to suit your own friends and family.

Box size: 340mm x 250mm x 50mm
Book size: 297mm x 210mm
124 pp quiz book
CD-Rom
Wipe-clean score boards
Answer pad and pens
Score chart

29220.name: The Ultimate Family Quiz Kit
29220.description:
Part of the Ultimate Quiz Kits series.
The ultimate family quiz—over 2,000 questions for every level, from beginner to buff.

Contains everything required for a fun quiz at home, at work or in the pub. The CD-ROM allows you to print off questions to suit your own friends and family.

This title contains: 6 pens, question and answer CD-ROM, joker cards, score boards, answers pad, score chart, quiz cards

Box size: 340mm x 250mm x 50mm
Book size: 297mm x 210mm
124 pp quiz book
CD-Rom
Wipe-clean score boards
Answer pad and pens
Score chart

29221.name: The Ultimate Movie Quiz Kit
29221.description:
From the publisher:
Part of the Ultimate Quiz Kits series.
The ultimate movie quiz – over 2,000 questions for every level, from beginner to buff.

Contains everything required for a fun quiz at home, at work or in the pub.

The CD-ROM allows you to print off questions to suit your own friends and family.

Box size: 340mm x 250mm x 50mm
Book size: 297mm x 210mm
124 pp quiz book
CD-Rom
Wipe-clean score boards
Answer pad and pens
Score chart

29222.name: The Ultimate Rock and Pop Quiz Kit
29222.description:
From the publisher:

Part of the Ultimate Quiz Kits series.
The ultimate rock and pop quiz—over 2,000 questions for every level, from beginner to buff.

Contains everything required for a fun quiz at home, at work or in the pub. The CD-ROM allows you to print off questions to suit your own friends and family.

This title contains: 6 pens, question and answer CD-ROM, joker cards, score boards, answers pad, score chart, quiz cards

Box size: 340mm x 250mm x 50mm
Book size: 297mm x 210mm
124 pp quiz book
CD-Rom
Wipe-clean score boards
Answer pad and pens
Score chart

boardgamehonor.20328: 2008 As d'Or - Jeu de l'Année Nominee

29223.description:
In Marrakech each player takes the role of a salesperson who tries to outwit the others. In turn each player rolls the dice and then moves Assam, the market organizer. If Assam stops on an opponent’s rug, the player must make a payment to its owner before putting one of their own rugs on an adjacent space. When the last rug has been laid, the total number of visible rugs and the number owned by each salesperson are added up.


Game Summary
Everyone starts with 10 coins and the same number of carpets. On your turn, you may rotate Omar 90 degrees. Then roll die and move him forward as many spaces as showing (d6: 1, 2, 2, 3, 3, 4); if gets to edge of board, follow curve and continue moving in now row. If he lands on another player's carpet, pay that player 1 coin per square showing that is contiguous with the landed-on square. Then, place your carpet orthogonally adjacent to Assam (but may not directly overlay another carpet).

Game ends when all players have played all carpets. Each gets 1 coin per visible square. Player with most coins wins!
29223.name: Marrakech

29224.name: Operación Barbarroja
29224.description:
Operación Barbarroja (Operation Barbarossa) is a strategic wargame that portrays the Eastern Front during World War II. The game recreates the combats between the German and Soviet armies between 1941 - 1945.

In 1987 NAC released a series of mini-wargames consisting in this and two other titles ("Infantería" and "La carga de la brigada ligera"). Their boxes, boards and pieces were obviously of a smaller size than NAC´s regular games, and also their prices (I seem to recall that I paid about 700 pesetas by then).

Contents were: a 24x38 cms board, 112 counters, a tray for them, a special die, sheets and rules.

The game was conceived for two players, being its duration from about 30 to 120 minutes and its difficulty 5 in the NAC scale (high).

Counters could be organized in groups. The pieces within them were put aside on the grouping sheets, and numbered group counters were moved on the board. This was the first time I saw this method in a NAC game. They were really getting better and more "serious" comparing to the first ones they published...

29225.description:
The game represents any of the multiple combats between the North American and South Vietnamese armies against the Vietcong and North Vietnamese troops.

the game contains 360 counters.
29225.name: Vietnam

29226.name: El Zorro del Desierto
29226.description:
During World War Two, two great strategists, Montgomery and Rommel, nicknamed The Desert Fox (El Zorro del Desierto), fought in North Africa.

This game recreates the Afrika Korps campaign of 1941 to 1942.

The game contains 480 counters.

29227.name: Camino de la Gloria
29227.description:
Camino de la Gloria (Path to Glory) recreates an Allied commando attack against a Nazi heavy water factory in Norway.

Heavy water is necessary to build an atomic bomb, so the Germans captured this Norwegian heavy water factory. An Allied commando of Norwegian soldiers were sent to sabotage the factory.

29228.name: Caballeros del Aire: El Barón Rojo
29228.description:
Caballeros del Aire (Knights of the Air) is a highly tactical game based on the exploits of fighter pilots during World War I, such as the Red Baron (Barón Rojo).
The difficulties faced by these men in their risky missions are faithfully recreated.
(Translated from game catalogue).

NAC was clearly improving its games and making them more varied when "Caballeros del aire" appeared. The rules were longer and more detailed than most of the ones from previous games, and even included historical background.

Contents were:
-64x80 cms. mapboard
-counters
-plastic trays for the counters
-1 die
-Rulebook
-2 airplane control sheets

Number of players: 2-4 (but ideally 2)
Playing time: 120 min. approx.
Difficulty: average

29229.description: A single player paper and pencil game where you play as a pharaoh, how long can the reign last and what impact will individual pharaohs have on the world is the question this game seeks to answer.
29229.name: It's a Pharaohs Life

29230.name: El Submarino
29230.description: Inspired in the exploits of the famous captains and crews of the German submarines in World War II. A perfect game for fans of stealth wargames. Contains 400 counters (translation from the game catalogue).

29231.name: Time Factor
29231.description:
From the Box
Tic..Tic..Tic make your move before the time runs out. Flip the frame and challenge your opponent to try for 3 in a row ...Tic...Tic...Tic With every move the pattern changes, so it pays to think ahead.

Played on a 3 by 3 matrix with 3 counter of each 5 colours.

29233.name: Darkness and Glory
29233.description:
Darkness and Glory is a strategy card game of the underground world of the drow, also known as the dark elves.

Players represent the leaders of the great houses, large, extended families of dark elves bound by blood and ambition. It is the goal of each house to rise in power by gaining the favor of the evil deity they worship.

In Darkness and Glory, players compete for this favor in different crises by playing cards that represent military units, nobles and magical spells.

The game sets up and plays quickly, putting players directly into the action. Fate cards provide color and immerse the player into the chaotic society of the drow. No dice or random elements are in the game, allowing players to focus on the strategy and card play.

Components include:

five-page rulebook
45 soldier cards
32 noble cards
27 spell cards
24 fate cards




Available from Brothers-in-Arms Games at biagamesonline.tripod.com - check out the site and check out the game.

29234.name: Shatar
29234.description: Shatar is the form of chess played in and around Mongolia. It is played on an 8x8 non-checkered board. Each player has a set of 16 men: 8 chu (pawns) that move and capture as in international chess; a nojon (king) that moves as a chess king; a bers (big animal) that moves as a king+rook; two mor (horses) that move as knights; two temee (camels) that move as bishops; and two tereg (chariots) that move as rooks. Upon reaching the 8th rank, a chu promotes to a bers (only). There is no castling, and there are no initial double pawn moves except for the bers pawns.

29235.name: Ask Me Another!
29235.description: Trivia game billed as "The Great Fun Family Quiz Game" Great family quiz game. Its fun to challenge the family to a general knowledge contest. You can race ahead if you answer the questions correctly, but, watch out, the tough ones mean you will get sent back. What is the "patella" or who wrote"The day of the Jackal"? If you know the answer you may reach the top space first!

29236.name: Winnetou
29236.description:
Go west! Every player starts with his horse in St. Louis and has to pass "dark and bloody grounds" until he reaches Winnetou's pueblo. Lots of adventures are to be faced on the way.

By drawing action cards you encounter famous Cowboys and Indians. You can be captured and freed. You can meet bandits and kill grizzly bears. For all those adventures you get trophies.

The first player to reach the pueblo and having a calumet card ends the game. But the winner is the one with the most trophies.

29238.name: Monopoly: FedEx
29238.description: Collect FedEx offices around the world and improve them with Drop Boxes and Service Centers in this FedEx themed Monopoly. Comes with 6 tokens: FedEx Trade Networks Ocean Liner, FedEx Express Airplane, FedEx Custom Critical Truck, FedEx Home Delivery Dog, FedEx Freight Truck, and FedEx Ground Van.

29239.description:
From the back cover of the rules:

Crusader is a set of wargames rules that allow you to game some of the greatest battles in history from Biblical times to the Medieval period. Although written with 28mm figures in mind the rules are stand-based and so easily translate to any scale of model. The rules cater for many popular basing methods so there is absolutely no need to re-base your figures to be able to play Crusader.

At the heart of the rules is the concept that you are representing units of troops in battle rather than individual warriors. Dispensing with the traditional phases within a turn the unit-based mechanics allow for a fluid game that simulates the quality and training of troops rather than the abilities of a few super characters.

The rules have been created with the flexibility to allow armies from widely differing time periods to fight against each other through the use of a consistent points system. So if you want to fight William the Conqueror's Norman Army against Alexander's Macedonians feel free!
29239.name: Crusader Historical Miniature Rules

29240.name: Phoenix Horizons
29240.description:
The Event changed everything...

A once unending universe has been reduced to a few fringe systems known as the Outerlands. The tyrannical rule of the Galactic Federation has been erased and new nations have risen to stake their claim to the vacant throne. Limited planetary resources have forced rival fleets to engage in interstellar war. Massive star fleets lead by cunning commanders and dedicated crews fill the void with fire, plasma, and a never ending hail of bullets. All eyes are on you to lead your chosen fleet to victory and rise from the ashes of the Event.

29241.name: Die Belagerung von Laxia
29241.description: Rare Game about the Siege of the City Laxia

29242.name: Yellow Ribbon
29242.description:
Campaign Book 5
Yellow Ribbon - Rules for Indian Wars 1850-1890

designed by Greg Novak, publisher Ulster Imports

This 46 page A5 black and white booklet provides a background and rules for Indian Wars of the 1860s. Miniatures are typically 15mm Plain Indian wars range.

Figures represent from 2-5 actual soldiers (with 16 figures representing a troop). Sequence of Play is divided into several phases, including Command (where one of seven orders are issued to army units, and one of six to Indians), Movement, Fire, Morale/Medicine and Close Combat.

Both sides can Hold and Move, but the Army can March, Reform, Charge, Mount/Dismount, and Disengage. The Indians can Close, Skirmish, Withdraw and Watch. And the use of Medicine Points to determine what various bands do is well done.

There is an associated booklet "And Continually Wear The Blue" sub-titled "A Short Guide to the US Army and the Indian Wars 1850-90", about half background on army organization and tactics and about half scenarios.

both "Yellow Ribbon" and "And Continually Wear The Blue" are originally published 1988, revised 1989

29244.name: Tombstone
29244.description:
The game is played by taking a tour of the town of Tombstone; the first person to complete the tour by traveling all the way around the board is the winner.

CONTENTS:
Game board
1 six-sided die
Six game pieces
Twelve "Miner's Chest" Cards
Twelve "Gamble" cards

This game was created as a tie-in to tourism in Tombstone Arizona.

29246.description:
The game is tied in to a popular children's TV programme of the era, in which presenter Shaw Taylor used to ask viewers to 'keep em peeled' on the watch for stolen goods and missing cars. The box cover carries the logos of London Weekend Television and ATV, and a picture from the show.

The large map represents the roads of the West End of London around which players move according to dice-rolls, choosing to walk, bus or use the tube, each of which allows different styles of movement.
